sources.text: Joseph Potts was born 1742-03-12 and he died 1804-02-04.
sources.citation: Exeter Monthly Meeting, Genealogy of Berks via Ancestry.com search, viewed July 5th, 2021

snacControlMetadata.note: Contributors from initial SNAC EAC-CPF ingest

biogHists.text: Joseph Potts was a minister associated with the state of Pennsylvania. He was born 1742-03-12 (Old Style) and died 1804-02-04. He had 10 children, John, Mary, Joseph Jr, Sarah, Joseph Jr, Anna, Frances, Phineas, Mary, and Joseph Kirkbride.

resource.title: John Hunt papers, 1770-1828.
resource.abstract: John Hunt kept a diary for more than 40 years, recording Quaker concerns and daily events. This collections consists primarily of the manuscript journal, 1770-1800; fragments of 1805, 1806 & 1808; and 1814-1824. Of particular interest are the visits of prominent Quakers, including Elias Hicks and Jonathan Evans. There is also an account book, some correspondence received, and other miscellaneous materials. Correspondents include Ann R. Matlack, Asa Matlack, Elizabeth A. Lippincott, John Cox, Joseph Foulke, and Josiah Roberts.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:86094013</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-DEH</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Coventry Forge (Coventryville, Pa.).</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Account book, 1787-1789.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The account book dates from the minority of Thomas Potts III, and shows accounts for a variety of iron, repair work and sale of stores.  Important accounts are those of Ellis Jones, Thomas Potts, Joseph Potts, Samuel Potts, John Galloway and Thomas Bull.  There is at least one reference to a "negro" slave worker. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hagley Museum & Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Account book, 1787-1789.
resource.abstract: The account book dates from the minority of Thomas Potts III, and shows accounts for a variety of iron, repair work and sale of stores.  Important accounts are those of Ellis Jones, Thomas Potts, Joseph Potts, Samuel Potts, John Galloway and Thomas Bull.  There is at least one reference to a "negro" slave worker.
